choices.text: Improve clinical symptoms and reduce hospitalization.
No role as it is useful only in HF with preserved EF
Diuretics and ACE inhibitors are better options

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with acute onset shortness of breath. He had a similar episode one month ago, for which he received injections as an outpatient. On examination, his BP is 140/88 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Auscultation reveals bilateral basal crepitations. A 2D echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction of 20%, and NT-proBNP > 2000 pg/mL. A diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is made. What is the ideal role of the sacubitril-valsartan combination in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sacubitril-valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) indicated for patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) to reduce symptoms, hospitalizations, and mortality.

  • Sacubitril is a pro-drug that inhibits neprilysin, an enzyme that degrades natriuretic peptides (ANP, BNP), bradykinin, and other vasoactive peptides. Inhibition of neprilysin leads to increased levels of beneficial natriuretic peptides, resulting in vasodilation, natriuresis, diuresis, and reduced cardiac remodeling.
  • Valsartan, an ARB, is combined with sacubitril to counteract the increased angiotensin II levels caused by neprilysin inhibition.
  • Sacubitril-valsartan is preferred over ACE inhibitors in symptomatic HFrEF (EF < 40%) as it provides greater reductions in hospitalization and mortality.
    • Note: It should not be used with ACE inhibitors due to risk of angioedema, and a 36-hour washout period is necessary when switching from an ACE inhibitor to ARNI.

Explanation of Other Options:

Risks more than benefits (Option B): Sacubitril-valsartan is well tolerated and shown to have greater benefit than ACEI alone, with a favorable safety profile when used correctly.

No role as it is useful only in HF with preserved EF (Option C): The strongest evidence and indication for sacubitril-valsartan is in HFrEF (EF ≤40%), not HFpEF. In HFpEF, benefit is modest and still under investigation.

Diuretics and ACE inhibitors are better options (Option D): While diuretics help relieve symptoms, they do not modify long-term mortality. Sacubitril-valsartan is superior to ACE inhibitors in HFrEF and is now recommended as a preferred alternative.

choices.text: Neprilysin inhibition and Angiotensin 2 type I receptor blocker
Neprilysin inhibition and Angiotensin 2 type 2 receptor blocker
Angiotensin 1 receptor blocker and neprilysin inhibitor
Neprilysin inhibitor and no effect on angiotensin receptorD) Neprilysin inhibitor and no effect on angiotensin receptor

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents for a routine follow-up. She was diagnosed with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) one month ago. Her medications include a beta-blocker, an ARB, a diuretic, and a sacubitril-valsartan combination. She reports improvement in symptoms. By what mechanism does sacubitril-valsartan work?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sacubitril-valsartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Neprilysin Inhibitor (ARNI). It combines:

  • Sacubitril: A neprilysin inhibitor. Neprilysin degrades natriuretic peptides (ANP, BNP), bradykinin, and other vasoactive substances. Inhibition leads to increased levels of natriuretic peptides, which promote vasodilation, natriuresis, diuresis, and inhibition of pathological cardiac remodeling.
  • Valsartan: An angiotensin II type 1 receptor (AT1) blocker, which inhibits vasoconstriction and aldosterone secretion mediated by angiotensin II.

This dual mechanism both enhances beneficial natriuretic peptide pathways and blocks harmful RAAS activation. It has been shown to reduce mortality and hospitalization in HFrEF.

choices.text: Associated with a reduction in cardiovascular deaths and heart failure events
Useful only in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and heart failure
Useful only in patients with Type 1 diabetes mellitus and heart failure
Only beneficial in reducing heart failure events but has no role in reducing cardiovascular deaths

questions.text: Which of the following about Dapagliflozin in heart failure is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dapagliflozin, a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, was originally used for glycemic control in diabetes but is now a recognized agent in the treatment of heart failure with reduced and preserved ejection fraction (HFrEF and HFpEF).

  • It works by reducing glucose reabsorption in the proximal renal tubules, causing glycosuria and osmotic diuresis, which leads to decreased preload and afterload.
  • These hemodynamic effects, along with metabolic and anti-inflammatory benefits, lead to improved cardiac function.
  • Dapagliflozin lowers the risk of heart failure hospitalization and cardiovascular death, and these benefits are independent of the patient's diabetic status. (Options B & D ruled out)
  • Its use is not recommended in Type 1 diabetes due to the risk of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 64-year-old female with heart failure is diagnosed with non-valvular atrial fibrillation. Which of the following scores helps in guiding the need for anticoagulant therapy for stroke prevention?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is the recommended tool to assess stroke risk in patients with atrial fibrillation and guide the initiation of anticoagulation.

Interpretation:

  • Score 0: No anticoagulation needed
  • Score 1: Consider anticoagulation (risk-benefit assessment)
  • Score ≥2: Anticoagulation strongly recommended

In this patient: CHF (1 point) + female sex (1 point) = 2 points → anticoagulation required.

Explanation of Other Options:

TIMI score (Option A): Used to estimate 14-day mortality and risk of recurrent ischemic events in patients with unstable angina/NSTEMI, not in atrial fibrillation.

ACC-AHA pooled cohort equation (Option B): Estimates the 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) (MI, stroke), but not specifically for AF-related stroke risk.

HAS-BLED score (Option D): Assesses the 1-year risk of major bleeding in patients receiving oral anticoagulation. It complements but does not replace CHA2DS2-VASc.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with breathlessness, visual blurring, and headaches. During examination, he develops a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His blood pressure is 240/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy shows retinal hemorrhages and exudates, and the optic disc margin is not visualized.
Which of the following medications is the first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with malignant hypertension (hypertensive emergency), characterized by severely elevated BP (>180/120 mmHg) with evidence of target organ damage, such as encephalopathy (seizure) and papilledema (blurred optic disc margin).

First-line management of malignant hypertension requires rapid yet controlled BP reduction using intravenous agents to prevent further organ damage.

  • Sodium nitroprusside is considered one of the first-line drugs due to its immediate onset (seconds), short half-life (1-2 min), and potent arterial and venous vasodilation.
  • It acts via release of nitric oxide (NO), which increases cGMP and relaxes vascular smooth muscle.
  • Recommended dose: 25-10 mcg/kg/min IV infusion, with close BP monitoring.

Intravenous drugs used for urgent BP reduction in malignant hypertension include:

  • Sodium nitroprusside
  • Labetalol
  • Nitroglycerin
  • Nicardipine
  • Esmolol
  • Hydralazine
  • Fenoldopam

Explanation of Other Options:

Furosemide (Option B): While diuretics like furosemide may be adjuncts in fluid overload or pulmonary edema, they are not first-line for acute BP reduction in hypertensive emergencies.

Nifedipine (Option C): Oral or sublingual nifedipine is contraindicated in hypertensive emergencies due to risk of uncontrolled BP drop, which can cause stroke, MI, or renal ischemia.

Atenolol (Option D): Atenolol, a beta-blocker, has slower onset and is not preferred in hypertensive emergencies compared to agents like labetalol or esmolol.

choices.text: At high risk of heart failure (HF) without structural heart disease
Structural heart disease with prior symptoms of HF
Structural heart disease with current symptoms of HF
Structural heart disease without signs or symptoms of HF

questions.text: Which of the following is the accurate description of Stage B heart failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ACC/AHA has divided heart failure evolution into 4 stages.

Reference: Heart Failure (Congestive Heart Failure) - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is investigated for dyspnea and is found to have an ejection fraction (EF) of 45% on echocardiography. How is the left ventricular ejection fraction calculated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ejection fraction (EF) is the percentage of blood ejected by the ventricle relative to the total amount of blood present in the ventricle at the end of diastole. It is calculated as:

Where:

  • Stroke Volume (SV) = End Diastolic Volume (EDV) - End Systolic Volume (ESV).
  • A normal EF is typically >55%, indicating efficient pumping.
  • In this case, an EF of 45% indicates mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction, which falls into the category of Heart Failure with mildly reduced EF (HFmrEF).

questions.text: In a patient with heart failure who is intolerant of ACE inhibitors/ARBs, which of the following is best suited to provide a survival benefit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors or ARBs, the combination of nitrates and hydralazine provides a survival benefit.

  • Hydralazine acts as an arterial vasodilator, reducing afterload, while nitrates primarily cause venodilation, decreasing preload. The combined effect leads to reduced cardiac workload and improved cardiac output, which is particularly beneficial in HFrEF patients.
  • This combination is especially useful in RAAS blocker intolerance (e.g., due to renal dysfunction, hyperkalemia, or angioedema).

Explanation of Other Options:

Ivabradine (Option A): Ivabradine selectively inhibits the funny (If) current in the SA node, reducing heart rate. It is indicated for symptomatic HFrEF (EF ≤35%) with HR ≥70 bpm despite optimal beta-blocker therapy. However, it does not replace RAAS blockade and its primary benefit is symptomatic improvement and reduced hospitalizations, not superior survival benefit compared to nitrates + hydralazine.

Digoxin + Frusemide (Option B): Both provide symptomatic relief. Digoxin improves contractility and decreases hospitalizations, while frusemide provides diuresis. However, neither agent improves long-term survival.

Bosentan (Option C): It is an endothelin receptor antagonist mainly indicated for pulmonary arterial hypertension, not for HFrEF, and does not provide survival benefit in systolic heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs improves myocardial contractility via calcium sensitization of cardiac muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Levosimendan is a unique positive inotropic agent that enhances myocardial contractility without increasing intracellular calcium concentrations, thus avoiding an associated rise in myocardial oxygen demand.

  • It acts by sensitising cardiac troponin C to calcium, enhancing actin-myosin interaction and contractility in a calcium-dependent manner, a mechanism known as calcium sensitisation.
  • Additionally, levosimendan also opens ATP-sensitive potassium channels in vascular smooth muscle, causing vasodilation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Milrinone (Option B) is a phosphodiesterase-3 (PDE3) inhibitor that increases intracellular cAMP levels, resulting in increased calcium influx and positive inotropy, not via calcium sensitisation.

Omecamtiv mecarbil (Option C) is a cardiac myosin activator. It enhances the efficiency of actin-myosin interaction and increases contractility without altering intracellular calcium levels, but it does not act via calcium sensitisation of troponin C.

Dobutamine (Option D) is a β1-adrenergic agonist, which increases myocardial contractility by increasing intracellular cAMP and calcium, not by calcium sensitisation.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man with a history of ischaemic heart disease presents with shortness of breath and reduced functional capacity, limited to walking around his home. Echocardiography reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of ~20%. He is already on maximal medical therapy for heart failure. ECG shows sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 75/min and widened QRS complexes (QRS: 160 ms). What is the most appropriate treatment option at this stage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), with an LVEF of ~20%, classified as NYHA Class III based on limited activity tolerance. He is already on optimal guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT).

The presence of widened QRS complex (160 ms), most often associated with left bundle branch block (LBBB), indicates ventricular dyssynchrony, which contributes to poor systolic function and worsened heart failure symptoms.

In such patients, Cardiac Resynchronisation Therapy (CRT), also called biventricular pacing, has been shown to:

  • Improve ventricular synchrony
  • Increase cardiac output
  • Reduce hospitalisations
  • Improve mortality and quality of life

Indications for CRT include:

  • LVEF ≤35%
  • Sinus rhythm
  • QRS ≥150 ms (especially with LBBB morphology)
  • NYHA Class II-IV symptoms despite optimal therapy

This patient meets all of the above.

Explanation of Other Options:

Addition of Perhexiline therapy (Option A): Perhexiline is a metabolic modulator with limited use and not part of standard HF therapy. Its role is investigational and restricted due to hepatotoxicity and neuropathy.

Increase diuretic dose (Option B): Diuretics are used for symptomatic relief of congestion but do not improve mortality or reverse cardiac remodeling. This patient is already on optimal therapy and symptomatic despite it.

Referral for implantable defibrillator (Option C): While an ICD may be indicated for primary prevention in HFrEF (LVEF <35%), CRT is prioritized here because of ventricular dyssynchrony (QRS ≥150 ms). ICDs do not improve mechanical efficiency of the heart.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with an 8-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus is currently being treated with metformin 1 g twice daily and gliclazide 80 mg daily. He is obese, has gained weight over the last year, and his HbA1c has worsened from 7.5% to 7.9%. His physician decides to discontinue gliclazide and initiate pioglitazone. Which of the following is a typical side effect of pioglitazone therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione (TZD) and functions as a PPAR-γ agonist, enhancing insulin sensitivity in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and the liver. While effective in glycemic control, its side-effect profile is well known and limits its use in certain populations.

A typical and common adverse effect of pioglitazone is fluid retention, which occurs in up to 10% of patients. This may manifest as peripheral edema and can exacerbate or precipitate congestive heart failure. Therefore, pioglitazone is contraindicated in NYHA class III-IV heart failure.
Fluid retention risk increases when used concurrently with agents like calcium channel blockers.

Other notable adverse effects include:

  • Weight gain
  • Reduction in bone mineral density → increased fracture risk, especially in postmenopausal women
  • Macular edema (hence contraindicated in severe diabetic retinopathy)
  • Hematocrit reduction due to hemodilution
  • Potential risk of bladder cancer

Explanation of Other Options:

Acanthosis nigricans (Option A) is a clinical marker of insulin resistance, not a side effect of pioglitazone. In fact, pioglitazone improves insulin sensitivity and may reduce acanthosis nigricans.

Lactic acidosis (Option C) is a rare but serious complication associated with metformin, not pioglitazone.

Myositis (Option D) is more typically seen with statins, especially in combination with fibrates. Pioglitazone is not commonly associated with muscle inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component assessed in NYHA functional classification in heart failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Classification is a widely used system to categorize heart failure severity based on the degree of functional limitation during physical activity.

The symptoms evaluated in this classification include:

  • Fatigue (Option A ruled out)
  • Dyspnea (Option D ruled out)
  • Palpitations (Option C ruled out)
  • Angina

These symptoms are used to determine how heart failure impacts daily physical activities.

Syncope, although a serious cardiovascular symptom, is not included in the NYHA classification criteria. It is typically evaluated separately as part of investigations into arrhythmias, structural heart disease, or neurocardiogenic causes.

choices.text: Reduce heart rate by inhibiting funny currents in SA node

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism with which beta blockers improve outcomes in HFrEF?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Beta blockers are a cornerstone in the management of HFrEF (Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction) and have been proven to improve mortality and morbidity in several landmark trials, including COPERNICUS, MERIT-HF, and CIBIS-II.

Their primary mechanism involves:

  • Decreasing heart rate
  • Reducing myocardial contractility
  • Blunting sympathetic nervous system overactivity that contributes to disease progression

By reducing both heart rate and contractility, beta blockers lower myocardial oxygen consumption, which leads to improved energy efficiency, reduced ischemia, and attenuation of harmful neurohormonal activation. Over time, this results in reverse remodeling of the heart and improved systolic function.

Explanation of Other Options:

Reduces both preload and afterload (Option B): This describes the action of ACE inhibitors or nitrates, not beta blockers. Beta blockers do not significantly affect preload or afterload directly.

Reduce heart rate by inhibiting funny currents in SA node (Option C): This is the mechanism of ivabradine, not beta blockers. Ivabradine selectively inhibits the If (funny) current in the SA node.

Increase cardiac contractility (Option D): Beta blockers initially reduce contractility. Over time, through reverse remodeling and decreased workload, cardiac output may improve, but this is not due to direct inotropic effects.

questions.text: A 77-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus requires improved glycaemic control. He also has heart failure which is currently controlled with diuretics and ACE inhibitors. Which of the following hypoglycaemic agents is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rosiglitazone, a thiazolidinedione (TZD), improves insulin sensitivity by activating PPAR-γ receptors, particularly in adipose tissue. However, its use is contraindicated in patients with heart failure, especially NYHA Class III or IV.

  • Mechanism of harm: Rosiglitazone can cause fluid retention of unclear etiology, which may precipitate or worsen congestive heart failure (CHF).
  • Associated effects include:
    • Dilutional anaemia (↓Hb by 1-2 g/dL)
    • Peripheral oedema, particularly ankle swelling
  • It is also contraindicated in hepatic impairment, as liver metabolism is required for drug clearance.
  • Due to these adverse cardiovascular outcomes, rosiglitazone carries a black box warning by the FDA regarding heart failure risk.

Thus, in a diabetic elderly male with established heart failure, rosiglitazone is absolutely contraindicated.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acarbose (Option A) is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate absorption in the gut. It is weight-neutral, does not cause hypoglycaemia, and is safe in heart failure. GI side effects (flatulence, bloating) are its main limitations.

Glipizide (Option B) is a second-generation sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion. It can cause hypoglycaemia, especially in the elderly, but is not contraindicated in CHF. Caution is required if there is significant renal impairment.

Nateglinide (Option C) is a meglitinide that increases insulin release but has a shorter half-life than sulfonylureas. It is useful for postprandial glucose control and is not contraindicated in heart failure.

questions.text: Digoxin has a narrow therapeutic index, and various factors can affect its plasma concentration. Which of the following conditions is most likely to increase the risk of digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that exerts positive inotropic effects by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, increasing intracellular calcium in cardiac myocytes. However, it has a narrow therapeutic window, and several conditions can precipitate toxicity.

  • Hypokalemia is one of the most important risk factors for digoxin toxicity.
    • Potassium competes with digoxin for binding to Na+/K+ ATPase.
    • Low serum potassium increases digoxin binding to the enzyme, enhancing its effects and risk of toxicity, even if serum digoxin levels are within therapeutic range.
  • Symptoms of digoxin toxicity include GI disturbances, visual changes (e.g., xanthopsia), arrhythmias, and CNS symptoms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypocalcemia (Option A): Hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, increases the risk of digoxin toxicity due to increased intracellular calcium. Hypocalcemia may actually decrease digoxin effects.

Liver disease (Option B): Digoxin is primarily excreted by the kidneys, not the liver. Hence, liver disease has minimal impact on digoxin clearance and toxicity.

Hyperthyroidism (Option D): Though hyperthyroidism may reduce digoxin efficacy (due to increased metabolic rate), it does not increase toxicity. In fact, hypothyroidism may increase serum digoxin levels due to reduced clearance.

choices.text: It is released in response to ventricular volume and pressure overload
Level of NT-proBNP correlate with severity of heart failure
Levels fall after initiation of definitive therapy for heart failure
Levels fall in old age and renal dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding NT-proBNP?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

NT-proBNP (N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide) is a well-established biomarker of cardiac stress, particularly in the diagnosis, monitoring, and prognostication of heart failure.

  • Production: It is released from ventricular myocytes in response to increased wall stress, due to volume or pressure overload. (Option A ruled out)
  • Clinical relevance: NT-proBNP levels correlate with the severity of heart failure and typically fall in response to effective treatment, making it a valuable tool to monitor therapeutic response. (Options B & D ruled out)
  • However, NT-proBNP levels do not fall in elderly individuals or in renal dysfunction, in fact, they increase. This is due to reduced clearance and comorbid factors increasing ventricular strain.

Conditions causing elevated NT-proBNP (other than heart failure):

  • Renal dysfunction
  • Old age
  • Critical illness
  • Anemia
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Sepsis
